item.title:
A province in Argentina (La Rioja) recently defaulted on its internationally subscribed debt, yet it publicly stated that it still maintains a Hotmail account for receiving questions from investors.
Argentina ü§£.

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: This might sound weird, but before Pectra EL clients didn‚Äôt have to ‚Äúknow‚Äù that the deposit contract was special because the CL just read from it directly.
Now, because deposits can be triggered by the EL and aren‚Äôt delayed by 2048 blocks (to account for PoW reorgs pre-merge), they do.
This issue was triggered because the Holesky (and Sepolia) deposit contracts are at a different address than mainnet. Why? I have no idea üòÖ
item.dc:creator: @TimBeiko
item.description:
This might sound weird, but before Pectra EL clients didn‚Äôt have to ‚Äúknow‚Äù that the deposit contract was special because the CL just read from it directly.

Now, because deposits can be triggered by the EL and aren‚Äôt delayed by 2048 blocks (to account for PoW reorgs pre-merge), they do.

This issue was triggered because the Holesky (and Sepolia) deposit contracts are at a different address than mainnet. Why? I have no idea üòÖ

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: ‚ú® ZK-Newsflash! ‚ú®
Here are the highlights of what happened in the ZK space from February 17th to 23rd.
Stay Aligned with recent industry updates each week by following and reading this thread.
‚úÖ @drakefjustin and @fede_intern discussed @ethereum's Native Rollup Roadmap on @therollupco Podcast
‚úÖ @class_lambda and @alignedlayer shared benchmarks for zkVMs
‚úÖ The recording for the first Beam Chain Call, dedicated to the social layer, is now live
‚úÖ @HerodotusDev introduced Atlantic, a managed ZK Prover service
‚úÖ zkVMs are now live on @SindriLabs
‚úÖ Introducing Neo, a Lattice-based folding scheme for CCS over small fields and pay-per-bit commitments
1/
item.dc:creator: @alignedlayer
item.description:
‚ú® ZK-Newsflash! ‚ú®

Here are the highlights of what happened in the ZK space from February 17th to 23rd.

Stay Aligned with recent industry updates each week by following and reading this thread.

‚úÖ @drakefjustin and @fede_intern discussed @ethereum's Native Rollup Roadmap on @therollupco Podcast

‚úÖ @class_lambda and @alignedlayer shared benchmarks for zkVMs

‚úÖ The recording for the first Beam Chain Call, dedicated to the social layer, is now live

‚úÖ @HerodotusDev introduced Atlantic, a managed ZK Prover service

‚úÖ zkVMs are now live on @SindriLabs

‚úÖ Introducing Neo, a Lattice-based folding scheme for CCS over small fields and pay-per-bit commitments

1/

item.title:
Today we had a lot of fun with @nickwh8te in Barcelona.
He is very humble, cool, smart and professional.
Every person we have met from @celestia is great. Bullish on great people!

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: .@drakefjustin and @fede_intern discussed @ethereum's Native Rollup Roadmap on @therollupco Podcast.
The episode, hosted by @Robbie_rollup and @ayyyeandy, covers Based & Native Rollups, implementation challenges, and their implications for Ethereum's future.
2/
item.dc:creator: @alignedlayer
item.description:
.@drakefjustin and @fede_intern discussed @ethereum's Native Rollup Roadmap on @therollupco Podcast.

The episode, hosted by @Robbie_rollup and @ayyyeandy, covers Based & Native Rollups, implementation challenges, and their implications for Ethereum's future.

2/

item.title:
So many ZK papers and here we are, everyone running STARKs in production and nothing comparable from the ZK paper industry.
The only thing I don't know much about that I'm really interested is the lattice work done by Consensys.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
So many ZK papers and here we are, everyone running STARKs in production and nothing comparable from the ZK paper industry.

The only thing I don't know much about that I'm really interested is the lattice work done by Consensys.

item.title:
RT by @fede_intern: Excellent question.
First, let me give you some context: we have been using Rust since 2014 and our team knows the core team of Rust pretty well. We are also the biggest supporter of Gleam (https://gleam.run) and one of the biggest companies using Erlang in production for the last decade. We have a history of using niche languages in production. Using Rust now is somewhat mainstream. In 2014 people asked us the same thing "why not just use C++"? At the end we're building concrete because we believe we can build something better.
What you are seeing is almost Rust. We want to be very similar to Rust syntax wise and in many areas. The big difference with Rust is that Concrete is a context free LL(1) language with linear types and a default runtime that is not turned on by default. Let me explain this in simple words: - The language is easy to parse and compile - It has a runtime like tokio but with guarantees like Go or Erlang. The runtime will not be turned on by default. It's only gonna be added if you use libraries like HTTP and IO related things - Linear type times are an improvement over affine types like the one of Rust. This is the biggest and huge improvement. I highly recommend you watching https://youtu.be/Ab8WQ1wwhV8 and reading https://blog.lambdaclass.com/austral/ and https://austral-lang.org/spec/spec.html
We believe Rust became huge and slow to change. We're minimalists and we a simple small compiler. With linear types the borrow checker is super simple. We are creating a simple Rust like language with linear types that enable the management of any resource.
I have never been a fan of convincing people in these subjects. I'm more a doer. Once it's ready, as with ethrex, I think people will try it and understand why and what we built. We only need a few more months of work and we will be giving talks and showing off the relevant differences. I highly recommend you to give it a try when it's working.
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
Excellent question.

First, let me give you some context: we have been using Rust since 2014 and our team knows the core team of Rust pretty well. We are also the biggest supporter of Gleam (gleam.run) and one of the biggest companies using Erlang in production for the last decade. We have a history of using niche languages in production. Using Rust now is somewhat mainstream. In 2014 people asked us the same thing "why not just use C++"? At the end we're building concrete because we believe we can build something better.

What you are seeing is almost Rust. We want to be very similar to Rust syntax wise and in many areas. The big difference with Rust is that Concrete is a context free LL(1) language with linear types and a default runtime that is not turned on by default. Let me explain this in simple words:
- The language is easy to parse and compile
- It has a runtime like tokio but with guarantees like Go or Erlang. The runtime will not be turned on by default. It's only gonna be added if you use libraries like HTTP and IO related things
- Linear type times are an improvement over affine types like the one of Rust. This is the biggest and huge improvement. I highly recommend you watching piped.video/Ab8WQ1wwhV8 and reading blog.lambdaclass.com/austral‚Ä¶ and austral-lang.org/spec/spec.h‚Ä¶

We believe Rust became huge and slow to change. We're minimalists and we a simple small compiler. With linear types the borrow checker is super simple. We are creating a simple Rust like language with linear types that enable the management of any resource.

I have never been a fan of convincing people in these subjects. I'm more a doer. Once it's ready, as with ethrex, I think people will try it and understand why and what we built. We only need a few more months of work and we will be giving talks and showing off the relevant differences. I highly recommend you to give it a try when it's working.

item.title:
I won't be in Denver. I'm working with Aligned and Lambda team in Barcelona, about to travel to Middle East and Africa.
The great @lean_knack, @JuanBono, @pablodeymo from @class_lambda will be there. @diego_aligned from @alignedlayer.
If you want to meet let me know!
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
I won't be in Denver. I'm working with Aligned and Lambda team in Barcelona, about to travel to Middle East and Africa.

The great @lean_knack, @JuanBono, @pablodeymo from @class_lambda will be there. @diego_aligned from @alignedlayer.

If you want to meet let me know!

item.title: 1. We're scaling the L1 2. We're launching based rollups that will be very fast and cheap with good interoperability with Ethereum. They don't compete with Ethereum. 3. Native rollups will remove many of the security problems of rollups 4. No need to bridge anywhere, real world usage of blockchains is in Ethereum growing by the day
item.dc:creator: @fede_intern
item.description:
1. We're scaling the L1
2. We're launching based rollups that will be very fast and cheap with good interoperability with Ethereum. They don't compete with Ethereum.
3. Native rollups will remove many of the security problems of rollups
4. No need to bridge anywhere, real world usage of blockchains is in Ethereum growing by the day

nitter.freedit.eu/MaxResnick1/status/1893756373583774015#m
